titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Bacon Family Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday April 6, 2019 at 07:16

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, newspaper clippings of a historical and religious nature, journals, and other papers of the Bacon family. Included are sermons and writings of Leonard Bacon; papers and journals of Leonard Woolsey Bacon and Benjamin Wisner Bacon; correspondence and printed material pertaining to the affair of Delia Salter Bacon and Alexander MacWhorter, a licentiate; and correspondence about the scandal between Henry Ward Beecher and Theodore Tilton regarding Beecher's affair with Tilton's wife, Elizabeth Tilton. Additional papers include diaries of Leonard Bacon; notebooks, letterbooks, manuscripts, and printed matter concerning the Congregational Church in Connecticut; correspondence, manuscripts, printed matter, newspaper clippings, and photos of four generations of the Bacon Family; and correspondence of Leonard Woolsey Bacon.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gifts from various members of the Bacon family ranging from 1940-1996.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Materials in Part II, with the exception of some materials in boxes 1, 2, and 7, are available on microfilm (HM 65). Patrons must use microfilm instead of originals.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown, though much of the material in this collection is likely in the public domain. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Bacon Family Papers (MS 46). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Letters relating to the Amistad case are available on microfilm (275 frames on 1 reel, 35mm.) from Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library, at cost. Order no. HM2.
Sermons and theological lectures of Leonard Bacon also available on microfilm (15,775 frames on 17 reels, 35mm.) from Scholarly Resources, Wilmington, Delaware.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Leonard Bacon (1801-1881) was a clergyman, educator, and writer. Leonard Bacon was active in many theological associations and church organizations. He was pastor of the First Church of New Haven from 1825 until his death in 1881. Reverend Bacon was an ardent abolitionist and a member of the Underground Railway prior to the Civil War. He was first married to Lucy Johnson (1800-1847) and then to Catherine Terry (1813-1882).
Benjamin Wisner Bacon (1860-1932), B.A. 1881. Born January 15, 1860, in Litchfield, Connecticut. Died February 1, 1932, in New Haven, Connecticut.

Father, Reverend Leonard Woolsey Bacon (B.A. 1850, M.D. 1856, D.D. 1879) son of Reverend Leonard Bacon (B.A. 1820; D.D. Hamilton 1843; LL.D. Harvard 1870) and Lucy (Johnson) Bacon, of New Haven and Boston. Mother, Susan (Bacon) Bacon; daughter of Nathaniel Almoran and Almira (Selden) Bacon, of Lyme, Conn. Yale relatives include: Benjamin W. Bacon, '47 (uncle), and his sons, Leonard B. Smith, '94, and Winthrop D. Smith, '96; Rev. Edward W. Bacon, '69 D., and Rev. Thomas R. Bacon, '72 (uncles); Alfred T. Bacon, '73 (uncle), his sons, Roger T. Bacon, ex-'11 S., and Alfred H.T. Bacon, '14, and his daughter Agnes W. Bacon, '24 Art; and Leonard Bacon, '09, Wallace G. Corwin, '17, Leonard W. Bacon, ex-'17, and Selden D. Bacon, '31 (nephews).

Hopkins Grammar School, Coburg Gymnasium, Germany and College de Genève, Switzerland. First Berkeley Premium in Latin composition Freshman year; first dispute appointment Junior and Senior years; second Winthrop Prize Junior year and Townsend Senior years; member Freshman Football Team; substitute on University Football Team Junior year and member Senior year; member Yale Orchestra; graduate member Elihu Club (elected 1916).

B.D. 1884 (on University Football Team while in Divinity School); ordained to Congregational ministry 1884 and pastor at Lyme, Conn., until 1889; pastor in Oswego, N.Y., 1889-1896; instructor in New Testament Greek at Yale 1896-97; Buckingham professor of New Testament criticism and interpretation 1897-1928 and professor emeritus since 1928; internationally recognized scholar of New Testament criticism; M.A. Yale 1892; D.D. Western Reserve 1893, University of Breslau 1911, Harvard 1914, and Yale 1929; Litt.D. University of Syracuse 1895 and Oxford 1920; LL.D. Illinois College 1904; delivered first Kent Shaffer Memorial Lectures at Yale 1930; also gave Earl Lectures at University of California 1911 and 1924, Hibbert Lectures at Manchester College, Oxford, 1920, and Lowell Lectures 1921; president of Society of Biblical Literature an Exegesis 1902-03 and managing editor of its journal 1907-08; resident director of American School of Oriental Study and Research at Jerusalem 1905-06; in 1928 through his negotiations, Yale received concession from the British Government to excavate a portion of ancient city of Jerash (Gerasa) in Palestine, in cooperation with British School of Archaeology; representative of the department of New Testament science at World's Congress of Arts and Sciences at St. Louis Exposition 1904; author: The Genesis of Genesis (1891), The Triple Tradition of the Exodus (1894), Introduction to the New Testament (1900), The Sermon on the Mount (1902), The Story of St. Paul (1904), Modern Religious Problems (1909), The Beginnings of Gospel Story (1909), The Bible for Home and School (1909), The Fourth Gospel in Research and Debate (1909), The Founding of the Church (1909), Commentary on Galatians (1909), Jesus, the Son of God (1911), The Making of the New Testament (1912), Theodore Thornton Munger, New England Minister (1913), Christianity Old and New (1914), Is Mark a Roman Gospel (1919), Jesus and Paul (1920), The Teaching Ministry for Tomorrow (1923), He Opened to Us the Scriptures: A Study of Christ's Better Way in the Use of Scripture (1923), The Apostolic Message (1925), The Gospel of Mark (1926), The Story of Jesus (1927), Studies in Early Christianity (1928), Studies in Matthew (1930), and Kent Shaffer Memorial Lectures (1930); his manuscript on the Gospel of John, entitled The Gospel of the Hellenists, has been prepared for publication early in 1933 by his literary executor, Professor Carl. H. Kraeling, of the Yale Faculty; author also of numerous pamphlets; had contributed to Journal of Biblical Literature , Anglican Theological Review , Biblical World , Yale Review , Harvard Theological Review , Journal of Religion , American Journal of Theology , Expositor , New World Magazine , New Republic , Yale Scientific Magazine , The Independent , and New York Sunday Times ; on American editorial board of Hibbert Journal 1908-1918; managing editor of Annual of American Schools of Oriental Research 1922-23 and 1924-25; editor of Leonard Bacon, a Statesman in the Church by Rev. Theodore D. Bacon, '83 S. (1931); honorary member Oxford Society of Historical Theology; member New York Reform Club, Good Government Club, Law and Order League, Civil Service Reform Club, National Council for Social Service in Connecticut, Victoria Institute of London, League of Nations Non-Partisan Association, and the Church of Christ in Yale University (acting pastor 1908-1916); secretary and treasurer of Yale Divinity School Alumni Association 1920-29 and of Connecticut Branch, Divinity School Alumni Association, 1916-1922; secretary of Class of 1884 D. since 1923.

Married May 27, 1884, in Norwich, Conn., Eliza Buckingham, daughter of William Appleton and Eliza Coit (Buckingham) Aiken, and sister of Alfred L. Aiken, '91. Children: Dorothy Buckingham, ex-'09 Art the wife of Heathcote M. Woolsey, '07; and Benjamin Selden (B.A. 1911, LL.B. 1916).

Death due to coronary thrombosis. Buried in Grove Street Cemetery, New Haven. Survived by wife, daughter, son, four grandchildren, four sisters, Margaret W. Corwin, the wife of Professor Robert N. Corwin, '87, S. Almira Bacon (Ph.D. 1911), Mabel G. Ripley, the wife of Philip F. Ripley, and Elizabeth R. Greene, the wife of Prescott M. Greene, '03 S., two brothers, Selden Bacon, ex-'83, and Leonard W. Bacon, '88 and '92 M., and a half brother David L. Bacon, '16 S. His oldest brother, Nathaniel T. Bacon, '79 S., died in 1926, and another brother, Rev. Theodore D. Bacon, '83 S., in 1930.
The Benjamin Wisner Bacon biography is taken from Yale University Obituary Record , 1931-1934, pages 53-55.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Friedrich Giesbrecht, Die Berufsbegabung der Alttestamentlichen Propheten [ The Gracious Calling of the Old Testament Prophets ?], 1897, printed, removed and sent to Divinity School.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence, newspaper clippings of a historical and religious nature, journals, and other papers of the Bacon family. Included are sermons and writings of Leonard Bacon; papers and journals of Leonard Woolsey Bacon and Benjamin Wisner Bacon; correspondence and printed material pertaining to the affair of Delia Salter Bacon and Alexander MacWhorter, a licentiate; and correspondence about the scandal between Henry Ward Beecher and Theodore Tilton. Additional papers include diaries of Leonard Bacon; notebooks, letterbooks, manuscripts, and printed matter concerning the Congregational Church in Connecticut; correspondence, manuscripts, printed matter, newspaper clippings, and photos of four generations of the Bacon Family; and correspondence of Leonard Woolsey Bacon.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Formerly owned by Mrs. Francis Bacon, Mrs Robert Corwin, the Trowbridge Estate, and H.D. Dana.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Part I consists of correspondence, papers, newspaper clippings and journals of four generations of Bacon family members—David Bacon (1771-1817) to Seldon Bacon (1861-1946). It thus provides a wealth of material which is especially pertinent to major social and religious issues of the latter half of the 19th century. The greater part of the correspondence and papers are those of Leonard Bacon (1802-1881), clergyman, educator and writer. The collection contains many of his articles on various religious and political topics. His sermons were printed in many publications and his funeral orations were well known and reprinted by many of his colleagues. His extensive correspondence with his family, friends, and political leaders is included in the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Part I is arranged in four series: Series I, Correspondence, contains letters between the entire Bacon family as well as friends and associates, and forms the bulk of the collection. The letters are arranged chronologically, headed by a description of the correspondence from 1817-1881. Series II, the Subject file, contains various legal and business documents and papers of the Bacon family, biographical data, lists of Leonard Bacon's discourses and publications, and other miscellaneous items. Series III, Manuscripts, contains writings of the Bacon family, material pertaining to church organizations, reports and minutes of various clubs and committees, writings of others, and unidentified or anonymous writings. The final section, Series IV, contains printed matter, consisting primarily of newspaper clippings, magazine articles and pamphlets, and news clipping scrapbooks, all relating predominately to religious and social issues, such as church affairs, temperance, and slavery, but also to a wide range of other topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the correspondence between four generations of members of the Bacon Family as well as correspondence with friends and associates. A great part of the correspondence is that of the Reverend Leonard Bacon. The first folder in the series is a description of correspondence between the years 1817 and 1881 and the rest of the folders are arranged chronologically. The series ends with a folder for undated correspondence, arranged alphabetically, and a letterbook of L. W. Bacon, 1874-1876 (largely illegible).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains deeds, lists, and other business papers of Leonard Bacon, T. R. Bacon, and B. W. Bacon. It also includes two lists of Leonard Bacon's sermons and discourses; maps of Connecticut and Massachusetts, 1662; a Biblical musical score; index of reading subjects; and biographical data concerning Michael and Leonard Bacon. The folders are arranged alphabetically by subject matter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series begins with essays, sermons, articles, and other writings of Leonard, Leonard W., and T. R. Bacon, respectively. Following this is a section relating to various church organizations, then a section concerning other clubs, committees, and town meetings. Writings of others ensues, among which the description of the scandal and trial surrounding Leonard Bacon's sister and Alexander McWhorter, written by Catherine Beecher, is notable. After this where is a larger section of unidentified or anonymous works, many of which are probably by members of the Bacon family. The folders are arranged alphabetically by title, subject, or name of the organization, except under writings of others, arranged by author's name. At the end of the series, there are seven folders containing miscellaneous writings, usually very short or fragmentary, covering a wide range of topics, from notes on Akkadian inscriptions to thoughts on ecclesiastical and governmental bodies. Many items concern notes and commentary on Biblical passages. Much of the material in this series is of general historical interest, for example the copied excerpts from the journal of Ezra Stiles, under writings of others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of newspaper clippings, magazine articles and pamphlets, and newsclipping scrapbooks. There is also one folder containing the "Protest of the Minority" in the McWhorter trial, 1847. Most of the newspaper clippings are taken from The Independent, a religious newspaper, and many deal with the problem of slavery in the United States. The magazine articles and pamphlets are mostly of a religious nature, and cover such topics as local church affairs, temperance societies, and foreign missions. Many of the newspaper articles and pamphlets were written by the Reverend Leonard Bacon. The folders are arranged chronologically by year, with a special folder at the end of each section for undated items. The scrapbooks reflect only a general grouping chronologically and by subject matter.

did.unittitle: Slavery and the Choctaw Indian missions, Bushnell, denominational subjects and church doctrines

Mostly articles by L. W. Bacon and reviews of his writings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Part II of the Bacon Family Papers consists of the correspondence, book and sermon manuscripts, newspaper clippings, printed matter, and photos of four generations of the Bacon family, 1819-1933, most notably Leonard Bacon, 1802-1881, Leonard Woolsey Bacon, Sr., 1830-1907, and Leonard Woolsey Bacon, Jr., 1865-1939. The bulk of the collection consists of the manuscript sermons of Leonard Bacon, the historical and theological writings of Leonard Woolsey Bacon, Sr. and Theodore Davenport Bacon, Jr. In addition, there are newspaper clippings and printed articles, lectures, and sermons by several members of the family pertaining to history, religion, congregational polity, and medicine, as well as reform movements, such as, temperance and abolition. Much of the correspondence is personal and pertains to family affairs, but a considerable amount is also devoted to public and professional matters. Of special interest is the Leonard Bacon—Henry Ward Beecher correspondence, 1852-1876, most of which pertains to the Beecher-Tilden controversy. Bacon played a prominent part in this episode serving as moderator for a council of churches called by Beecher's enemies in 1874, and again for a council held in Plymouth Church in 1876. In addition, there is an interesting and important correspondence between Leonard Bacon, a leading champion of temperance, and his brother, David Francis Bacon, who was an alcoholic, that sheds much light on the prevailing attitude toward the problem of alcoholism.
Music manuscripts and printed materials have been sent to the Music Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Part II is arranged in four series: Series I. Correspondence; Series II. Subject file; Series III. Pinted matter; Series IV. Manuscripts.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials in Part II, with the exception of some materials in boxes 1, 2, and 7, are available on microfilm (HM 65). Patrons must consult microfilm instead of originals.

altformavail.p: Part II, with the exception of some materials in boxes 1, 2, and 7, is available as HM 65 and from Scholarly Resources, Wilmington, Delaware.. Patrons must consult the microfilm instead of the originals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of day journals and diaries of Leonard Bacon with accounting and memorandum sections. 35 items. 1828-1881 [if the months are not listed, the diary covers the entire year; an asterisk (*) means loose items have been removed, enclosed in bond paper, and placed in folder 8].

did.unittitle: Items removed from day journals and letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Included are checks, receipts, accounting lists, notes and note fragments, hymns, advertisements, calling cards with Leonard Bacon's signature, clippings, ALS, prescription, trolly ticket, list of names, outline, resolution, and a piece of Arnica Court Plaster ["cures Rheumatism, Sciatica, Pleurisy..."].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Items belonging to Leonard Bacon, regarding the Congregational ministry and theology, records of secular and ecclesiastical associations, letterbooks.
An asterisk (*) indicates that items have been removed, enclosed in bond, and placed in folder 8.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The addition consists of material bearing upon Professor Bacon's pastorate at Oswego; classroom and lecture notes; manuscripts of articles published; and unpublished manuscripts. The unpublished manuacripts are the most significant. They number 84 and comprise of the most part, essays, articles and addresses ranging in date from 1881 to 1932. Included are the manuscripts of four books: "Papias and the Apostolic Tradition", the lectures delivered at Oxford in 1912, "The Book Q and the Synoptic Problem" (undated), "The Development of Synoptic Tradition" (1919), and "The Gospel of the Hellenists" (1929-1932).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This addition to the Bacon Family Papers consists primarily of photographs of a trip to Palestine and Europe taken by Benjamin Wisner Bacon, lectures on religion, and administrative documents regarding the Yale University Divinity School. The bulk of the photographs are of landscapes and ruins; a few photographs include unidentified individuals, as well as some photographs of his children, Dorothy Buckingham Bacon and Benjamin Selden Bacon. This material spans from 1900-1920.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This addition was separated from the collection and was kept with the Babylonian collection for unknown reasons. It was discovered in early 2017 and transferred back to MSSA. The names on the folders were taken from the description provided on the individual sleeves holding both the envelopes and the negatives.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: These materials contained silver nitrate negatives of all the photographs that, due to Manuscripts and Archives policy, have been removed from the collection. These negatives contained similar images that are represented in the addition.
